thread.title: ACCC eyes monitoring crackdown to keep ISPs honest
thread.title_full: ACCC eyes monitoring crackdown to keep ISPs honest | Business Spectator

author: Mitchell Bingemann
title: ACCC eyes monitoring crackdown to keep ISPs honest
text:
The competition regulator is considering how to implement an in-home broadband monitoring service that will help it crack down on misleading download speed promises by internet service providers.
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has just completed a trial of the monitoring service with 90 Melbourne-based volunteers’ who agreed to have their fixed-line broadband connections monitored for the past three months.
The trial has seen volunteers install a hardware probe on their home broadband connection which monitored their download/upload speeds, web browsing time, latency, packet loss and video streaming quality.
The trial found a noticeable trend in deteriorating performance during peak use periods, particularly in relation to download speeds.
If the scheme was implemented in a formal capacity it would help inform consumers about real-world broadband performance and help identify internet providers that fail to deliver advertised broadband speeds.
The collection of real-world broadband experiences will be a vital for consumers when choosing an internet provider as the move to the NBN.
High-quality broadband performance information is not currently easily available to consumers and will become particularly relevant for NBN consumers due to the heightened service performance expectations of the NBN, the ACCC said.
In addition, it will be a useful tool for verifying claims about speed performance, something that is expected to be a more prominent feature of NBN offers, which are marketed for specific speed tiers
“The ACCC believes a broadband performance monitoring and reporting program would promote competition and consumer outcomes by providing transparency over the quality of broadband services,” ACCC Chairman Rod Sims said.
“As the NBN rollout progresses, providing transparency over the performance of the monopoly network provider will be particularly important as retail service providers (RSPs) will be dependent on NBN Co for the underlying network capability. In this regard, visibility over any network-based performance issues would help identify whether any bottleneck issues in the network are attributable to RSPs or the network provider.”
Mr Sims said the ACCC was greatly encouraged by the results of its trial, but a decision to proceed with a future program has not been made and any finalised program would require further stakeholder consultation. Plans on how the program would be funded have also not been finalised.
